dt.t: the town in which he {it}dwelled{/it} for eight years
where the heart of the matter {wi}dwells{/wi}
tried not to {wi}dwell{/wi} on my fears

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}dwellan{/it} to go astray, hinder; akin to Old High German {it}twellen{/it} to tarry

dt: {bc}one (such as a prehistoric human) that dwells in a cave
{bc}one that lives in a city apartment building

shortdef: one (such as a prehistoric human) that dwells in a cave
one that lives in a city apartment building

dt: {bc}a last-place team {bc}a team with the worst record in a league, conference, etc.

dt.t: Northwestern University, long a {wi}cellar dweller{/wi} in the Big Ten, defied all odds and went to the Rose Bowl in 1995.
… any team in the majors—including the {wi}cellar dwellers{/wi} from the season before—has the chance to be the best in the game.
The Aggies have morphed from conference {wi}cellar dweller{/wi} to annual contender to a program that has won 17 consecutive home games …

shortdef: a last-place team : a team with the worst record in a league, conference, etc.

dt: {bc}a member of a prehistoric American Indian people of the southwestern U.S. who built their homes on rock ledges or in the natural recesses of canyon walls and cliffs
{bc}a resident of a large usually metropolitan apartment building

shortdef: a member of a prehistoric American Indian people of the southwestern U.S. who built their homes on rock ledges or in the natural recesses of canyon walls and cliffs
a member of any cliff-dwelling people
a resident of a large usually metropolitan apartment building

dt: {bc}a dwelling built on piles in a lake

shortdef: a dwelling built on piles in a lake; specifically : one built in prehistoric times
